column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Consolidate blog
username_0: * [x] Checked to see if the issue has already been discussed before ü§îÔ∏è
* [x] If proposing new content to be added, made sure enough details were provided üîçÔ∏è
<issue_comment>username_1: I think this is a great idea. How were you thinking? I'd still like to use medium.
<issue_comment>username_0: Medium is great but the site would get more traffic since the blog posts are all hosted in the same place.

It also allows for more customization like an email newsletter section at the bottom of every blog post.

We could also automate the sharing of blog posts and events so that anytime there is a new one created, it will take the updated RSS feed and can share to Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.
<issue_comment>username_0: Users are also more likely to explore rest of Techqueria website since they are not leaving the site for Medium.
<issue_comment>username_2: @username_0 @username_1 I recently heard about this site generator called Gatsby that's great for making starter blog if we decide to navigate away from Medium 

[https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-blog](https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-blog )

[https://medium.freecodecamp.org/how-to-build-a-react-and-gatsby-powered-blog-in-about-10-minutes-625c35c06481](https://medium.freecodecamp.org/how-to-build-a-react-and-gatsby-powered-blog-in-about-10-minutes-625c35c06481)
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_2 Hugo works great for this as well and we can bake it right in! üòÑ 

@dvidsilva Would you be okay with us making this transition from Medium to self hosted on https://techqueria.org? What are your thoughts on this? 

If it's cool, I think we should move forward with copying existing blog posts and transferring them to https://techqueria.org.
<issue_comment>username_1: lets migrate the existing blog posts @username_0
<issue_comment>username_1: closing this<issue_closed>

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Give partials the same template inheritance logic as `.Render`
username_0: Currently `.Render` is the only way to benefit from the content directory template logic (based on section/type) with partial templates.
But `.Render` requires a Page context and cannot cache its produced markup (√† la `partialCache`).

User can devise a way to replicate this complex template inheritance for its partials using `templates.Exists` etc... but I wonder if Hugo could not sport the feature with minimum if no code breaks at all.

### Basic example
```
layouts
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _default
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄsingle.html
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ list.html
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ recipes
‚îÇ    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ single.html
‚îÇ    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ partials
‚îÇ        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ sidebar.html
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ partials
         ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ sidebar.html
```

With the above layout directory, user could use the same partial call `{{ partial sidebar.html }}` from both `_default/single.html` and `recipes/single.html` and let Hugo check for the existence of an "overriding" partial.

I'm merely bringing this up to start a discussion for it is hard for me, as a user, to grasp its technical complexity.
<issue_comment>username_1: I guess this would be ... possible somehow. But in my head, this is what we have base templates for. Admittedly we should improve the "lookup logic" in that area (there is an issue about that somewhere), but I think that if you want to make an argument for the value of this particular feature, I think you need to come up with a better example than a sidebar (which I think fits much better in the `baseof.html` setting).
<issue_comment>username_1: Also, I don't think you would get "the same template inheritance logic as `.Render`" without a ... page; that `.Render` cannot determine its layout without knowing the page.
<issue_comment>username_0: Oh yes.... Didn't think about that. It would mean the partial call somehow must guess which section (directory) to look for. Can't think of any safe way for this to be guessed when `partial` is used.

It's a shame, I would love to see the power of `partialCache` brought to any template file.
<issue_comment>username_1: As I said, what would probably be possible is to use the partial that lives in the "current template section" (I made that up). e.g. `recipes/single.html` => `recipes/partial/foo.html`.
<issue_comment>username_0: Indeed, wouldn't this get too complicated if partial is used inside of another partial ? Having to navigate back to the initial template file's location?
I think shortcodes use the template logic of regular template files, so I suppose if the "root" template file found is a shortcode, you could identify the directory?

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'ncksllvn', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2018-03-12T21:02:37Z', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "- The beta stuff is now hooked up to the API\r\n- Adds a component that handles redirects from the index page to the dashboard. It does this by intercepting links going to the index page. It is attached conditionally, meaning that it is only rendered for users who are logged in and enrolled in the beta. It is powered by the services property in the user object. This means that if you reload the page, then click a link before the user object is retrieved, then you will not be redirected. This is an acceptable edge case IMO since once we're out of beta we won't have to check for the beta flag.\r\n- ~~For now, I switched to a hackish method of redirecting from the index page to the dashboard - see the bottom <script> element on that index.md. The thing is that we currently need an immediate method of checking whether or not a user is enrolled in the beta to redirect from the homepage to the dashboard, because sometimes that /v0/user route takes awhile, and we need a redirect to be fast. For testing purposes, I added a flag into localStorage that enables beta features for the site which we can use to check immediately~~", 'title': 'Personalization dev beta cleanup', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'ncksllvn', 'comment_id': 372704770.0, 'datetime': '2018-03-13 15:24:48+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "@bshyong I actually feel great about this current solution. Once we go from beta to live, we may need to revise the redirect handler, but otherwise I think it's in great shape. No sessionStorage or localStorage necessary. You just need to enroll the user in the beta by visiting `http://localhost:3001/dashboard-beta/` or the profile.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Personalization dev beta cleanup
username_0: - The beta stuff is now hooked up to the API
- Adds a component that handles redirects from the index page to the dashboard. It does this by intercepting links going to the index page. It is attached conditionally, meaning that it is only rendered for users who are logged in and enrolled in the beta. It is powered by the services property in the user object. This means that if you reload the page, then click a link before the user object is retrieved, then you will not be redirected. This is an acceptable edge case IMO since once we're out of beta we won't have to check for the beta flag.
- ~~For now, I switched to a hackish method of redirecting from the index page to the dashboard - see the bottom <script> element on that index.md. The thing is that we currently need an immediate method of checking whether or not a user is enrolled in the beta to redirect from the homepage to the dashboard, because sometimes that /v0/user route takes awhile, and we need a redirect to be fast. For testing purposes, I added a flag into localStorage that enables beta features for the site which we can use to check immediately~~
<issue_comment>username_0: @bshyong I actually feel great about this current solution. Once we go from beta to live, we may need to revise the redirect handler, but otherwise I think it's in great shape. No sessionStorage or localStorage necessary. You just need to enroll the user in the beta by visiting `http://localhost:3001/dashboard-beta/` or the profile.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: feature request (again): https://github.com/leafo/scssphp
username_0: :)
<issue_comment>username_1: You can still use any higher level language for styles when developing a theme :-) Why add this to the core? Maybe a module is a better idea?
<issue_comment>username_0: Module sounds perfect for this, core would be overkill :)
Maybe i'l try to implement this in the theme-option.php module.
The idea is to provide sassy-powers to the users, not just the designer.
(i kinda want to modularise every thing with my theme)

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Content/power sequencer getting started
username_0: I've filled out most sections with text and instructions.

Some issues however:

1. I'd like to add .mp4s to demonstrate the features. I tried adding one but it wouldn't display on the page. I'm not sure if this is a limitation of the website or the file. I can play it just fine on my machine.
1. Setting the preview range using `Set Timeline Range` doesn't seem to work as I expect so I haven't filled that out as I'm not sure I understand it. I expect it to automatically set the range based on the strips selected but it just moves the start of the rendering range to the timeline cursor and doesn't change the end of the rendering range.
<issue_comment>username_1: This is another feature, you need to use `Preview to Selection`
<issue_comment>username_1: I'll let you finish the guide, tell me when it's time to review and do an editing pass.
<issue_comment>username_0: I've added the videos and finished of the remaining sections. It's ready for an edit.
<issue_comment>username_1: Good job, it's clear and to the point!

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'beckchris', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2020-06-01 08:13:51+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'We want many millions of people in Germany to install the app, right? To achieve this the landing page needs a much easier-to-understand language.

One example:
When looking at the german version of the website, one of the first senteces that the user reads is: "Das Exposure Notification Framework (von Apple und Google) auf einem mobilen Ger√§t sendet einen Rolling Proximity Identifier und sucht gleichzeitig regelm√§√üig mithilfe der Technologie Bluetooth Low Energy nach IDs anderer Smartphones und speichert die IDs lokal."

How many percent of people in Germany are able to understand this?

Don't forget that the challenge is not to develop this app, but rather to bring it onto the smartphones of about 50 million people in germany. So the marketing team should be larger than the development team.

Is there any strategy for that already in place?', 'title': 'Website needs simpler language', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'MalteJ', 'comment_id': 636704996.0, 'datetime': '2020-06-01 08:44:09+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': 'Hi Chris,

the idea for coronawarn.app is to get in contact with developers, tech freaks and people interested in the progress of the open source project. The target group of coronawarn.app is definitively not the broad population of Germany.
A separate PR campaign will be set up with the target to get a huge adoption.
I think the language is OK for the group we are targeting with coronawarn.app.

Malte', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

Christian', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Website needs simpler language
username_0: We want many millions of people in Germany to install the app, right? To achieve this the landing page needs a much easier-to-understand language.

One example:
When looking at the german version of the website, one of the first senteces that the user reads is: "Das Exposure Notification Framework (von Apple und Google) auf einem mobilen Ger√§t sendet einen Rolling Proximity Identifier und sucht gleichzeitig regelm√§√üig mithilfe der Technologie Bluetooth Low Energy nach IDs anderer Smartphones und speichert die IDs lokal."

How many percent of people in Germany are able to understand this?

Don't forget that the challenge is not to develop this app, but rather to bring it onto the smartphones of about 50 million people in germany. So the marketing team should be larger than the development team.

Is there any strategy for that already in place?
<issue_comment>username_1: Hi Chris,

the idea for coronawarn.app is to get in contact with developers, tech freaks and people interested in the progress of the open source project. The target group of coronawarn.app is definitively not the broad population of Germany.
A separate PR campaign will be set up with the target to get a huge adoption.
I think the language is OK for the group we are targeting with coronawarn.app.

Malte
<issue_comment>username_0: Hi Malte, okay I understand. Thanks for clarification.
Christian<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_2: If you like it I'm also happy to create a pull request.

I hope that also the marketing campaign will be created in an open way so it can be improved before hitting the broader public.

Best regards
Gregor

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: OpenShift Operator link broken
username_0: Going to the [openshift](https://cert-manager.io/docs/installation/openshift/#installing-with-cert-manager-operator) page, I noticed that the link

<https://catalog.redhat.com/software/operators/detail/5e999d862937381642a21c7a>

leads to nothing:

![Screenshot from 2021-05-11 07-46-40](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2195781/117764613-145f6280-b22d-11eb-867c-da40a40a7593.png)

What's weird is that the server does not return a 404, which means our dead link linter does not show any error:

```sh
% curl -si https://catalog.redhat.com/software/operators/detail/5e999d862937381642a21c7a | head -7
HTTP/2 200
x-powered-by: Express
server: Apache
cache-control: max-age=0
expires: Tue, 11 May 2021 05:41:09 GMT
x-ua-compatible: IE=edge
content-type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
```

[Searching](https://catalog.redhat.com/software/operators/search?q=cert-manager&p=1) for "cert-manager" does not return any result either, any idea?

cc @jakexks
<issue_comment>username_0: My issue is a duplicate of https://github.com/cert-manager/website/issues/486, so I'll close it.

/close

 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'dholbach', 'comment_id': 828169644.0, 'datetime': '2021-04-28 06:03:15+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': 'https://fluxcd.io/docs/migration/faq-migration/#is-the-gitops-toolkit-related-to-the-gitops-engine', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'Jean-Baptiste-Lasselle', 'comment_id': 840421976.0, 'datetime': '2021-05-13 08:57:56+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'Hi @username_1 ,

A word to seriously thank you for letting me know about "FluxCD and Gitops Engine, where are we?". That is very important information : 
* gitops engine has incompatibility with FluxCDF v2
* Now this is , tchnically, very important information : This means that at a conceptual level, there are divergence between Gitops Engine, and FluxCD
* In other words, FluxCD and Gitops Engine see gitops differently, think of gitops with different, incompatible concepts : Or the very interesting question here is "Do  they actually ? Is there not a set of concepts that could actually unify the two apparently incompatible approaches?"

This is why I am glad that the FluxCD project shows strength, and advocates its own concepts : It allows us to raise and think of higher level idea, because it will take a very powerful idea, to reconcile Gitops Engine (let's say it, ArgoCD), and FluxCD.

Thank you FluxCD Team / Stefan Prodan for your amazing opinionated work, I love FluxCD :)', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Update helmreleases.md
username_0: Hi, I believe, at https://fluxcd.io/docs/guides/helmreleases/#cloud-storage , I believe that you have a typo:  I think that it's a `FluxCD` `HelmRelease`, to helm release Chartmuseum, not a `HelmRepository`, see proposed change


Thank you very much fo he work done on the 2nd generation of `FluxCD` (btw, I did not find where the "gitops engine" common project with Argo CD is... any link ?)
<issue_comment>username_0: my msitagke, I jsut missed that the helm repository was the helm repository for the ChartMuseum Helm Chart, and then in same Ymal the Healm Release for Chart Museum
<issue_comment>username_1: https://fluxcd.io/docs/migration/faq-migration/#is-the-gitops-toolkit-related-to-the-gitops-engine
<issue_comment>username_0: Hi @username_1 ,

A word to seriously thank you for letting me know about "FluxCD and Gitops Engine, where are we?". That is very important information : 
* gitops engine has incompatibility with FluxCDF v2
* Now this is , tchnically, very important information : This means that at a conceptual level, there are divergence between Gitops Engine, and FluxCD
* In other words, FluxCD and Gitops Engine see gitops differently, think of gitops with different, incompatible concepts : Or the very interesting question here is "Do  they actually ? Is there not a set of concepts that could actually unify the two apparently incompatible approaches?"

This is why I am glad that the FluxCD project shows strength, and advocates its own concepts : It allows us to raise and think of higher level idea, because it will take a very powerful idea, to reconcile Gitops Engine (let's say it, ArgoCD), and FluxCD.

Thank you FluxCD Team / Stefan Prodan for your amazing opinionated work, I love FluxCD :)
